article.headline: Nikola shares take wild ride after denial of short-sellerâs allegations, report of SEC inquiry
article.body: Shares of electric-truck maker Nikola Corp. went on a wild ride Monday, as the Securities and Exchange Commission reportedly weighed a short-sellerâs claims of fraud, which the company had vehemently denied earlier in the day. After sinking around 8% in early-morning trading, shares of Nikola NKLA, -1.36% Â surged after the company issued a rebuttal, closing up more than 11%. But much of those gains evaporated after hours, following a Bloomberg News report that the SEC was looking into short-seller Hindenburg Researchâs claims. Nikola ended the extended session down 8%. Last week, Hindenburg called Nikola an âintricate fraud,â alleging the company made widespread false statements and false claims about its technology. On Monday morning, Nikola called that report âfalse and misleadingâ and offered a detailed rebuttal of Hindenburgâs accusations, citing âdozensâ of inaccuracies. But Nikola did not dispute that a 2018 promotional video giving the impression of a self-driving truck in action actually just showed the truck rolling downhill. Nikola ânever stated its truck was driving under its own propulsion in the video,â the company said. Nikola also said it had âproactively contacted and briefedâ the SEC about Hindenburgâs report, claiming it was designed to manipulate the market to benefit short sellers. In a statement, Nikola said it âwelcomes the SECâs involvement in this matter.â But its stock tumbled in extended trading after a late-afternoon report by Bloomberg that said the SEC is also looking into Hindenburgâs allegations that Nikola may have violated securities laws by deceiving investors. Bloomberg said the review is preliminary and may not result in an investigation. Wedbush analyst Dan Ives is taking a wait-and-see approach, saying Monday that Nikola is a âprove meâ stock, while keeping a neutral rating. Last week, Nikola shares shot higher after General Motors Co. took a $2 billion equity stake in the company and announced a âpotential game changingâ partnership to build an electric pickup. GM Chief Executive Mary Barra told CNBC on Monday that GM had conducted âappropriate diligenceâ ahead of the deal. Nikola shares have sunk 47% over the past three months, but are still up nearly 250% year to date.
